sense.gloss: introduction (e.g. to a rakugo story), lead-in
pillow word, decorative word used prefixally in classical Japanese literature
at the bedside where one dreams
place that is often written about in waka poetry
lying with one's head to the north (trad. position for dead bodies; taboo for sleeping)
brown-lined puffer (species of pufferfish, Canthigaster rivulata)
using one's arms as a pillow
resting one's head on one's arm or elbow
using one's arm for a pillow
laying one's head in someone's lap, using someone's lap for a pillow
pillow stuffed with buckwheat chaff, rice husks or similar material
pillow with a box-shaped wooden base
sleeping while on a sea voyage, falling asleep to the sound of the ocean
sleeping on grass in an open field

sdata.j: ↑私↑↓わたし↓は↑日本↑↓にっぽん↓の↑米↑↓べい↓↑枕↑↓まくら↓が↑好↑↓す↓きです。とても↑首↑↓くび↓に↑良↑↓よ↓いです。
sdata.e: I like Japanese rice pillows; they are good for my neck.

sdata.j: ↑修学旅行↑↓しゅうがくりょこう↓では、よく↑枕↑↓まくら↓↑投↑↓な↓げをした。
sdata.e: I had a lot of pillow fights during my school trip.

sdata.j: ↑通販↑↓つうはん↓で↑理想↑↓りそう↓↑的↑↓てき↓な↑枕↑↓まくら↓が↑買↑↓か↓えます。
sdata.e: An ideal pillow is available from a mail-order house.

sdata.e: She laid her head down on the pillow.
